thread.title: Insurers should have 5% of total number of policies in social sector tenth year onwards: IRDAI
thread.title_full: Insurers should have 5% of total number of policies in social sector tenth year onwards: IRDAI | Business Standard News

author: BS Reporter
title: Insurers should have 5% of total number of policies in social sector tenth year onwards: IRDAI
text:
Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI) has said that all insurers-life, non life and health insurance, should have atleast 5 per cent of their total lives covered to be from social sector once they are in operation for 10 years or above. Here, social sector includes unorganised sector, informal sector, economically vulnerable or backward classes both in rural and urban areas. It is 0.5 per cent for the first year of operation.
In its guidelines on rural and social sector obligations, IRDAI has said that every insurer should mandatorily do business in these segments. For the rural sector, which means the places or areas classified as rural as per the Census, life insurers have to write atleast 7 per cent of total number of policies in rural areas in their first year of operation. This goes up to 20 per cent from their 10th year onwards.
In respect of a general insurers, 2 per cent of gross premium income should be in rural segment in first year, which goes up to 7 per cent from the ninth year onwards. In respect of standalone health insurers, it is 50 per cent of the obligations prescribed for non-life insurers.
Here, the regulator said that micro insurance policies issued are eligible to be reckoned for the social sector obligations. Where a micro insurance policy is issued in a rural area, it can be reckoned for both rural and social sector obligations separately.
